Technical Chemistry Department of Chemistry Chemical-Biological Centre Umeå University Umeå SE-901 87 Sweden Graphical abstract The catalytic performances of two different classes of catalysts containing nickel or/and ruthenium as the active sites were studied in the depolymerisation of lignin isolated from Miscanthus × giganteus. The catalysts were prepared either by coprecipitation (ie, (RuNiMgAlO)x, (RuNiAlO)x, (NiAlO)x, (NiMgAlO)x) or by wet impregnation (ie, Ru/Al2O3) and characterized by nitrogen physisorption (BET), XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, Raman and H2-TPR techniques. The experimental results indicate that the presence of ruthenium led to dimers as dominant products. Keywords Lignin Hydrogenolysis Heterogeneous catalysts Ru-based catalysts 1 Introduction Conversion of lignocellulosic materials to renewable fuels or chemicals has attracted important attention due to imminent depletion of fossil fuels. Lignin, a dominant part of lignocellulosic materials, is the world’s most abundant natural aromatic polymer having a three dimensional structure based on phenolic monomeric units (ie, sinapyl, coniferyl and p-coumaryl alcohols) which are inter-connected by several types of linkages such as β-O-4, β-5, 5-5, 4-O-5, β-1, and β-β bonds. Among these, β-O-4 linkage is the most abundant, representing almost 50% of the native material [1]. Moreover, the energy of β-O-4 linkage is lower compared to the 5-5 (biphenyl)-type or aromatic ring structures [2], a feature that promotes the depolymerisation of lignin to low molecular mass compounds. The interest for lignin depolymerisation is motivated by the possibility of obtaining important platform chemicals such as aromatic aldehydes, acids, alcohols and phenols or using lignin derivatives as flavors or chemical intermediates for pharmaceutical drugs [3]. However, the depolymerisation of lignin is not an easy task, its complex structure, the probability to form some condensed structures during the thermochemical processes, the poor product selectivity towards monomers and the existence of various linkage types between monomeric units being the most important challenges [4]. The conversion of lignin to monomers and dimers requires the COC bond cleavage [5]. Several methods such as pyrolysis [6,7], hydrolysis [8], hydrogenolysis [5,9] oxidation [10,11] or hydrocracking [12] are reported in literature for this process. Among these, hydrogenolysis is considered as one of the most promising methods, the process leading to higher yields of monomers compared to other thermo-chemical methods [9]. However, selective hydrogenolysis of CO bonds is not a simple process since the average energy of this bond is higher than that of the other C-X single bonds (except CH and C-F bonds). As a result, the CO bond is difficult to break by most reagents and catalysts [13]. Noble metals as Pt, Rh and Ru supported on carbon carriers play an important role in the selective production of 4-ethylphenol and 4-ethylguaiacol by hydrogenolysis of lignin into ethanol/water solvent mixtures. The performance of Ru/C catalysts, the most efficient ones in this aspect, was influenced by the reaction temperature (an increase from 200 to 275 °C led to a yield increase for 4-ethylphenol from 0.79 to 3.1%). The obtained yields are comparable to those obtained via petrochemical routes [14]. The nature of the solvent is another parameter which can influence the distribution of products upon depolymerisation. Thus, using catalysts similar to the aforementioned ones, Yan et al. [5] reported a monomer yield of 46% (ie, guaiacylpropane, syringylpropane, guaiacylpropanol, syringylpropanol) at 200 °C in a dioxane/water solvent mixture. The importance of the solvent nature was also emphasized by Song et al. [15] upon lignosulfonate hydrogenolysis into phenols over Ni/AC. Therefore, the conversion could be increased from 2% to 68% by simply replacing the iso-propanol solvent with ethylene glycol. The depolymerisation of lignin over Ni/AC led only to aromatic products, the hydrogenation of these compounds being carried out in the presence of Pd/AC (Activated Carbon). Nickel gives rise to better performance in terms of the aliphatic CO bond cleavage than the aromatic CO bonds hydrogenolysis [15]. Moreover, Ni/Al-SBA-15 was more efficient compared to systems relying on supports such as ZrO2, Al2O3, Al2O3/KF or native SBA-15 [16]. Recently, Zhang et al. [17] reported NiM (M = Ru, Rh and Pd) catalysts as highly performing in the hydrogenolysis of CO bonds. The authors showed that the direct incorporation of 15% Ru led to an increased reduction rate of Ni as well as the formation of ultra-small bimetallic particles. Moreover, their catalytic activity was highly improved compared with NiRh and NiPd catalysts. Porous metal oxides (PMOs) obtained by the calcination of the corresponding hydrotalcites, doped with metals such as Cu, La, Mn, Cr and Zn, were recently used for the depolymerisation of lignin to oligomer and monomer aromatics, in supercritical methanol [18]. The best results in the conversion of lignin to oligomer aromatics soluble in methanol were reported for Cu- and La-doped PMO (Cu20La20PMO), suggesting a synergetic effect of copper and lanthanum. On the other hand, Garron et al. [19] observed a similar synergetic effect of metals upon conversion of pine wood to low oxygenated fuel over Rux/Cuy@CsWP and Rux/Cuy@CsMoP catalysts. Moreover, it seems that ruthenium can partly substitute Mg2+ or Al3+ cations into octahedral layers of hydrotalcite [20], absolutely necessary in the complete conversion of benzene to cyclohexane under 60 atm H2 at 120 °C. Recently, also Kim et al. [21] have demonstrated the synergistic effect between metallic Pd and Fe in the selective cleavage of CO bond from benzyl-phenyl-ether (used as lignin model due to the presence of α-O-4) to aromatic compounds as toluene and phenol. The improvement of the catalytic performances in the cleavage of CO bond due to synergistic effects was obtained via incorporation of noble metals into Ni [17]. Based on the above state-of-the-art observations and with the aim to improve the selective depolymerisation of lignin, herein we report the preparation and characterization of mixed oxides such as (NiRuMgAlO)x, (NiRuAlO)x, (NiAlO)x, (NiMgAlO)x and Ru-based mesoporous alumina. The catalysts were tested in lignin depolymerisation and the synergetic effect between Ru and Ni in terms of their catalytic performance was demonstrated. Therefore, whereas the cleavage of CO bond of α-O-4 and β-O-4 linkage is catalyzed by Ni [22], the addition of Ru could improve the selective hydrogenolysis of lignin to monomers or dimers [23]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Lignin extraction The lignin tested in this study was extracted from Miscanthus x giganteus by soaking of this raw material in aqueous ammonia solution (25 wt.%) for 6 h, at 60 °C, in a water bath [24]. The recovery of lignin from the obtained black liquor was carried out by precipitation in a sulfuric acid solution (pH = 2). The success of lignin extraction was evidenced by the presence of β-O-4 bonds in the structure of extracted material using NMR spectroscopy or by characteristic signals of aromatic ring vibrations of the phenylpropane groups recorded by FTIR spectroscopy [24]. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts All starting materials were of analytical purity, and used as received without any further purification: Ni(NO3)2 .6H2O, Mg(NO3)2 .6H2O, Al(NO3)3 .9H2O, RuCl3 .xH2O (Sigma-Aldrich), NaOH and Na2CO3 (Sigma-Aldrich), Al2O3 (Sigma-Aldrich). The layered double hydroxides modified with ruthenium were synthetized via partial substitution of Ni2+, Mg2+ or Al3+ by ruthenium cations (5 wt% Ru), following the procedure described in literature [20]. Thus, a 1 M solution (A) containing NaOH and Na2CO3 in 15 mL distilled water was added dropwise into a solution (B) containing either Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (1,92 g), Mg(NO3)2·6H2O (2,56 g), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (2,06 g), RuCl3·xH2O (0,22 g) or Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (5,82 g), Al(NO3)·9H2O (2,47 g), RuCl3·xH2O (0,2 g) in 18 mL distilled water under vigorous stirring. Then the supernatant was aged at 70 °C for 16 h in a Teflon coated stainless steel autoclave with the formation of a precipitate. After cooling to room temperature, LDH-based material was washed with distilled water to pH = 7, dried at 80 °C (12 h) and then calcined at 500 °C (4 h). The obtained materials were denoted as: (RuNiMgAlO)x and (RuNiAlO)x, respectively. For comparison, (NiMgAlO)x and (NiAlO)x mixed oxides were synthesized in accordance with the aforementioned procedure but without addition of RuCl3·xH2O in solution. Also 5 wt% Ru/(NiAlO)x was prepared by the wet impregnation of (NiAlO)x mixed oxide with RuCl3. We characterized this material after its calcination at 500 °C (4 h) using both Raman and XPS spectroscopy in order to compare it with (RuNiAlO)x mixed oxide and to evidence the presence of RuONi bond. The 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by the wet impregnation of mesoporous alumina with an aqueous solution of RuCl3 (0.14 g RuCl3·xH2O dissolved in 3.1 mL water). The obtained material was dried overnight at room temperature and then at 100 °C for 3 h, the reduction to Ru00 being carried out at 500 °C for 6 h under hydrogen flow. 2.3 Catalysts characterization Textural characteristics of the as prepared materials were determined using N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at −196 °C acquired by a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. The structural characterization was carried out using a Shimadzu XRD 7000 diffractometer using a CuKα monochromatic radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). The radiation intensity was measured with a scanning rate of 0.1 2θ min−1, in the 2θ range between 5 and 90. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of ammonia was performed using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 apparatus. The samples were first activated at 350 °C for 1 h and subsequently cooled to 40 °C under a helium flow. The activated materials were then saturated with 10 vol% ammonia in helium at the same temperature. When the adsorption was complete, the sample was purged with a helium flow to remove the physisorbed ammonia and then the NH3-TPD was performed at a rate of 10 °C/min until 500 °C. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were also carried out in the aforementioned system. The sample, placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor with an inner diameter of 0.5 cm, was pre-treated under He (Purity 5.0, from Linde) at 100 °C for 10 min and cooled to 50 °C. Then the sample was exposed to a flow of 5 vol% H2 in He (99.999% from SIAD) during heating with a rate of 10 °C/min until 700 °C. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded at room temperature using a PHI 5600ci Multi Technique Instrument. The pressure in the analysis chamber during the analysis was 1.33 mPa. Monochromatized AlKα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) was used. It was generated by bombarding the Al anode with an electron gun operated with a beam current of 12 mA and acceleration voltage of 10 kV. The spectrometer energy scale was calibrated using the Au 4f7/2 peak centered at 84.0 eVCharge correction was made with the C 1 s signal of adventitious carbon (CC or CH bonds) located at 284.8 eV. The Raman spectra were acquired in the extended spectral region from 150 to 4000 cm−1. Raman analysis was carried out with a Horiba JobinYvon − Labram HR UV–vis-NIR Raman Microscope Spectrometer, at 488 nm. 2.4 Catalytic tests Typical depolymerization experiments were carried out in autoclave conditions using 0.5 g lignin and 0.1 g catalyst in 70 mL methanol, for 6 h, at 180 °C, under 50 or 70 bar of H2 and vigorous stirring. After reaction, the unreacted lignin was recovered by the centrifugation of the mixture at 15.000 rpm for 10 min. The conversion of lignin to low molecular weight compounds was calculated using Eq. (1): (1) C % = m i − m f m i × 100 Where: mi = mass of lignin introduced in reaction mf = mass of lignin recovered after reaction The catalyst was recycled in four consecutive runs. After the first run, the catalyst and the remaining lignin were centrifuged and dried. Fresh lignin and methanol were added at the initial mixture and used for the next run under similar conditions. Analysis of the reaction products was made by recording the high resolution mass spectra with an Ultraflex MALDI-TOF-MS (matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization- time of flight-mass spectrometry) (Bruker Daltonic) operating in the reflector and linear positive or negative mode using a pulsed nitrogen laser (l 337 nm, pulse rate of 10 Hz) as the ionization source. The analyzer was used at an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. Laser light was focused on the sample using a 5.2 kV lens. A pulsed ion extraction was optimized to 200 ns. A peptide calibration set was used as the external standard. For each lignin sample, LDI-TOF-MS was ensured on 10 distinct sample deposit zones. A total of 300 shots were provided. Each sample preparation and analysis was duplicated. The peak average molecular mass distribution of lignin was evaluated by using a high performance size exclusion chromatography (HPSEC) with UV detection at 280 nm. The system was composed of a Waters 2690 Alliance chromatograph, coupled to a Waters 996 UV detector (both from Waters Corp., Milford, MA, USA), and equipped with a TSK-Gel PWxl guard column and two TSKgel G3000PWXL columns (300 mm × 7.8 mm I.D.) in series (with 7 and then 6 μm particle diameters, respectively) (Tosoh Bioscience, Tessenderlo, Belgium). A polynomial calibration curve was established by using a range of narrow distribution poly(4-styrenesulfonic acid) ammonium salt (PSS-Na) (Sigma-Aldrich, Diegem, Belgium) with average molecular masses from 208 Da to 77.4 kDa. The eluent solution contained 6.9 g NaH2PO4·H2O and 3.2 g NaOH in distilled water and the pH was adjusted to 12 with 6 M NaOH. The flow rate was 0.9 mL/min, at a temperature of 30 °C. Before use, it was filtrated over 0.45 μm filter and sonicated during 15 min. PSS-Na and lignins were dissolved in a volume of eluent, 1 mg/mL and 3 mg/mL, respectively. Before analyses, the lignin solutions were kept under magnetic stirring during 48 h to ensure a complete dissolution, and filtered through a 0.45 μm MCE membrane prior to injection. Analyses of phenolic compounds were carried by GC–MS, i.e. gas chromatography (HP GC System 6890 Series) coupled to mass spectrometry (HP Mass Selective Detector 5973) (Agilent Technologies, Diegem, Belgium). Separation was done on an Agilent J&Wcapillary column (FactorFour VF–5 ms, 30 m × 0.25 mm ID, 0.25 μm film thickness). Helium was used as carrier gas at a flow rate of 1 mL min-1. Injection chamber was set at 250 °C, and the temperature program was 8 min at 40 °C, followed by a linear increase at 5 °C min−1 to 250 °C and then at 2 °C min−1 to 300 °C which was maintained for 20 min. Compounds were detected using a flame ionization detector at 320 °C. Leaching of ruthenium was checked by the energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrometry technique (EDXRF). Thus, after reaction, the sample was diluted with distilled water (sample:H2O ratio of 2:7) and was then analyzed with the elemental analyzer spectrometer EDXRF (X-Calibur – Xenemetrix, Migdal Haemek, Israel) for its Ru content. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Table 1 shows the textural characteristics of the tested catalysts. The insertion of ruthenium in the structure of layered double hydroxides (Ni-(Mg)-Al) led to a considerable increase in the surface area. The XRD patterns of the prepared catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . The calcination of unmodified layered double hydroxides led to mixed oxides formation evidenced by recording of some broad diffraction lines corresponding to P-MgO (periclase) and B-NiO (bunsenite,) (Fig. 1 c and e) [25]. The presence of ruthenium oxide species, as tetragonal crystalline RuO2, was confirmed by the presence of diffraction lines at 28.1°, 35.2°, 54.3° (corresponding to (110), (110) and (211) planes respectively) [26]. Although the amount of Ru used in the preparation of catalytic materials was similar in both cases, due to the atomic radius of Ru3+ (0.068 nm) which is much closer to that of Ni2+ (0.069 nm) than to that of Mg2+ (0.072 nm) [27], a better substitution of Ru3+ with Ni2+ than with Mg2+ was observed (Fig. 1, b and d). Moreover, the introduction of Ru by substitution did not influence the parent structure of mixed oxides as outlined in Fig. 1 [28]. The slight decrease in the crystallinity of (RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x \ compared to their parent structures could be due to the introduction the ruthenium cations which led to an increase in the number of cations of higher ionic radii in the brucite sheet [29]. On the other hand, the presence of metallic ruthenium with (101) crystallographic face supported on alumina was highlighted by the observation of a diffraction line at 44° [30,31] (Fig. 1, a). The diffraction lines of RuO2 on the alumina surface could not be identified by XRD either due to the inclusion of ruthenium in the interstitial sites of the support or due to small quantity of ruthenium supported on alumina [32]. According to the literature data, the thermal decomposition of Mg-Al and Ni-Al LDHs lead to mixed oxides which are associated with both basic (due to the low coordination of O2− sites) and acidic (Al3+ ions) sites [33,34]. Besides the synthesis method, calcination temperature and the nature of the interlayer species, the relative amount of basic/acid sites depends both on the nature of M2+ cations and on the M2+/Al3+ ratio [33]. On the other hand, an increase in the Ni/Mg ratio shows a transformation to medium or high acidity due to an increase in the Ni2+ content (Fig. 2 ). However, introducing Ni2+ into the LDHs structure might lead to an increased acidity of the corresponding mixed oxide, but also to a synergistic effect of nickel and magnesium metals that would favor the basic properties of the surface of the catalyst [35]. 1.1 The desorption of ammonia for the Ru-containing catalysts shows various types of acidic sites taking into account the presence of desorption peaks in certain temperature ranges, as <210 °C (for weak acid sites), 210–380 °C (for medium acid sites) and >380 °C (for strong acid sites) [36]. No high and low temperature desorption peaks were observed for the (RuNiMgAlO)x catalyst, but only medium temperature with small intensities (Fig. 2A, curve b). The absence of Mg2+ ions from the LDH structure lead to mixed oxides which gives rise to all three types of acid sites (with various ratios of weak to strong acids sites on the surface of the catalysts) as observed for the (RuNiAlO)x sample (Fig. 2A curve a). On the other hand, the presence of the ruthenium led to an increase of Lewis acidity of these mixed oxides (Fig. 2B) [33], and follows the nickel content (Fig. 2.A) [37]. The increase in the (RuNiAlO)x acidity compared to that of (NiAlO)x can be due to the interaction of Ru with Ni (Fig. 2B) [38]. Despite the lower total acidity of Ru/Al2O3 compared to Ru-containing mixed oxides catalysts, its acid sites show the strongest acidity, with a maximum desorption peak located at 479 °C (Fig. 2A curve c) and an intermediate one located around 295 °C. The high-temperature peak was related to Ru0 species on which the decomposition of NH3 took place, while the middle-temperature peak was due to the release of ammonia desorbed from alumina, in agreement with literature [39]. The reducibility of Ru species from (RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x mixed oxides was studied by H2- TPR, in the temperature range of 50–500 °C (Fig. 3 ). Within this temperature range, both the reduction of ruthenium and nickel were recorded. The signals at 215 °C (for (RuNiMgAlO)x) or at 202 °C and 230 °C (for (RuNiAlO)x) could be assigned to the reduction of RuO2 (RuO2 + 2H2 → Ru0 + 2H2O) [26,32]. The peaks at 400 °C (Fig. 3 A) and 494 °C (Fig. 3B) can evidence the existence of some Ni2+ species not incorporated into the structure of mixed oxides, but bounded through weak interactions [40,41]. The temperature of reduction of nickel ions located at the surface of mixed oxides is higher than for bulk NiO due to a polarizing effect of aluminum ions on Ni-O bonds [42]. On the other hand, a strong interaction between Ru and Ni leads also to an increase of the reductibility of NiO [43] which explains the two different reduction temperatures for Ni2+, i.e. at 400 °C and at 494 °C. Moreover, the higher intensity of the signal at 215 °C (Fig. 3B) comparted to those recorded at 202 °C and 230 °C (Fig. 3A) suggests that the ruthenium is present both as bulk RuO2 or RuO3 and as species where weaker interaction between Ru and Ni occurs. The XPS measurements evidenced the presence of ruthenium in the analyzed samples ((RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x). Representative XPS spectrum of O1s is presented in Fig. 4 , while Table 2 lists the corresponding binding energies of Ru 3d and O 1s. All Ru 3d spectra exhibit a component at 284.27–284.41 eV, which is a pattern of Ru6+ state in RuO3 and also a component at lower binding energies (281.4 eV) corresponding to the Ru4+ state in RuO2 [44]. O 1s have three peaks, first one at 529.35–529.72 eV corresponding to RuO2 [45], another at 531.16-531.31 eV attributed to RuO3 [46] and the last one at 532.22-532.6 eV assigned to a CO bond [44]. The intensity of the peak attributed to RuO2 is much higher for (RuNiAlO)x than in the case of (RuNiMgAlO)x due to a better substitution of ruthenium with nickel. The binding energies of Ru 3d and O1 s for (RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x are similar and both are shifted compared with Ru/(NiAlO)x (Figure below and Table 2 in the manuscript). This shift can be attributed to the formation of RuONi bond. The presence and concentration of RuONi bond in (RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x mixed oxides were investigated by Raman spectroscopy and we correlated the interaction between Ru and Ni with the data obtained by XPS and XRD. A. Satsuma et al. reported the identification of RuOCe bond by Raman spectroscopy [47]. Taking into account this study and the Raman spectra of (NiAlO)x, we tried to assign the bands associated with the RuONi bond. A small Raman band at ∼375 cm−1 (Fig. 5 ) can be assigned to NiA12O4 [48]. As reported, for pure RuO2, weak sharp bands were identified at 522, 635, and 703 cm−1 assignable to Eg, A1g, and B2g modes, respectively [47]. These bands are not detectable in the spectra of (RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x, probably due to the interaction of Ru species with Ni2+. Two bands at ∼504 and ∼618 cm−1 which are assigned to RuO2 [49] were observed for (RuNiAlO)x and (RuNiMgAlO)x and were not detectable in the Raman spectra of (NiAlO)x. The intensities of these bands, in agreement with XRD and XPS data, are more higher in Raman spectra of (RuNiAlO)x compared to those obtained for (RuNiMgAlO)x which could be probably due to a stronger interaction probably between ruthenium and nickel. Moreover, the deposition of ruthenium on (NiAlO)x led to the formation of two peaks: one in the range 300–400 cm−1 and another in the range of 900–1200 cm−1 due to RuO2 presence in the bulk [50]. In contrast, the intensity of these bands is very small for (RuNiAlO)x, very likely due to dispersion of Ru in the (NiAlO)x network and RuONi bond formation. 3.2 Catalytic behavior The catalytic performances of the mixed oxides and ruthenium supported on alumina in the depolymerisation of lignin were evaluated by several techniques such as MALDI-TOF, HPCSEC and GC–MS. MALDI-TOF-MS is a technique widely applied to the analysis of oligomers from heterogeneous media [51–53] as well as to the characterization of large natural and synthetic polymers [54] due to little and/or no fragmentation of the analyzed molecules. MALDI-TOF-MS measurements have been applied to structural investigations of natural [55] or synthetic lignin [56], and to the study of lignin depolymerisation into monomers and oligomers [57]. Moreover, no limitations from superposing matrix signals in spectra at low molar masses (<400 Da) have been detected during lignin analyses using in this case LDI-TOF-MS [58]. LDI-TOF-MS analyses were carried out in this study in order to estimate the molecular weight distribution pattern of the constitutive fragments of lignin extracted from Miscanthus × giganteus after a heterogeneous catalytic depolymerisation reaction. In a previous study, the acetylated form of this lignin was found to have an average molecular mass of 3140 g mol−1, as determined by size exclusion chromatography [24]. The presence of ruthenium led to a better selectivity of the catalyst concerning the depolymerisation of the lignin (Fig. 6 ). According to the literature [59], the LDI-TOF-MS spectrum of the supernatant recovered after the catalytic lignin depolymerisation was composed of three distinguished groups of peaks which correspond to monomers (range of m/z 74–250), dimers (range of m/z 250–450) and tri- and tetramers (range of m/z 450–840). When lignin was depolymerized in the presence of (NiAlO)x, the LDI-TOF-MS spectrum (Fig. 5) covered a molecular mass range from 74 to 810 Da, leading to monomers (with dominant molecular mass signals, m/z of 136, 162, 167, 193, 197, 223), dimers (with dominant molecular mass signals, m/z of 272, 283, 297, 313, 327, 431) and tri- and tetramers (m/z of 463, 475, 493, 505, 518, 534, 562, 578). When (RuNiAlO)x was used, the molecular mass range was from m/z of 74–414 Da, giving rise to monomers (with dominant m/z of 193 and 223) and to dimers (with dominant m/z of 272 and 284). The phenolic rings with variable number of aliphatic side chains and/or HO groups which are most probably derived from (S) syringyl (m/z of 167, 197 and 223) units and (G) guaiacyl (m/z of 136) units, were observed at m/z ranges corresponding to monomeric ions [58,59]. The ions at m/z of 162 and m/z of 193 might be attributed to the characteristic ions [M-18]+ which result from the loss of water of coniferyl and sinapyl alcohol, respectively [61]. It is reported that G and S units are the dominant building blocks in the lignin extracted from Miscanthus × giganteus [62]. The presence of less G-units is most probably correlated to their greater reactivity of the G-units than S-units which induces repolymerisation [63]. The structures of monomers obtained after depolymerisation of lignin were also confirmed by GC–MS measurements. In the molecular mass range of dimeric products, some major species (m/z of 272, 283, 297, 302 313, 327 and 342) might be attributed to different biphenyl-, phenylcoumaran-, diarylpropane- and resinol-type structures [60]. A gap of both 12–14 Da and 16–18 Da between two adjacent peaks sequences reveals the sample heterogeneity related to the different numbers of C atoms/CH2 groups and different numbers of O atoms/HO groups presented in the molecule structure, respectively. However, these differences might be attributed to aliphatic structures with different linkages between the monomeric units of the lignin. It is difficult to establish the structures of the trimers obtained after depolymerisation of lignin due to multiples coupling between mono and dimers. However, in agreement with literature, m/z of 493 or 535 could have a structure of HHG and GGG type [64] and m/z of 562 or 578 could represent the GSG and GGG structures, respectively [65]. The structure of monomer and dimers compounds [60,66] are shown in Tables 3 and 4 , respectively. On the other hand, the information obtained by LDI-TOF-MS technique is only qualitative and quantification was carried out by HPSEC analyses of the reaction products. The analysis by chromatographic technique was in agreement with LDI-TOF-MS concerning the decreased monomer yield after depolymerisation of lignin over (RuNiAlO)x (Fig. 7 ). The mass differences between LDI-TOF and HPSEC analysis (higher molecular masses) could be due to the association of molecules during the HPSEC separation (i.e. hydrodynamic volume) [58,67,68]. Moreover, the polydispersity of the lignin have created many interpretation difficulties both in the case of LDI-TOF and HPSEC analysis [69]. The substitution of a part of nickel amount with Mg2+ led to lower catalytic performances (Fig. 6) compared with the results obtained over (NiAlO)x and (RuNiAlO)x, both in terms of conversion and yield. A molecular mass range from 74 to 838 Da, leading to: monomers (with dominant m/z of 140, 146, 148, 154, 162, 167, 193, 194, 223 and 241), dimers (with dominant m/z of 272, 283, 297, 302, 313, 328, 339, 342, 353, 355, 369 and 413) as well as to tri- and tetramers (with m/z of 417, 429, 432, 463, 493) was detected after depolymerisation of lignin in the presence of (NiMgAlO)x. Therefore, the differences in the fragmentation of lignin compared to (NiAlO)x were highlighted by the identification of new products such as guaiancyl (m/z of 140), syringyl (m/z of 154, 167, 181 and 197), a derivate of p-hydroxyphenyl (H) unit (m/z of 148) [60] as well as a C2-alkyl-benzofuran fragments (m/z of 146) [60]. A similar behavior of (RuNiMgAlO)x catalyst to that of (RuNiAlO)x in the depolymerisation of lignin was also observed by the retrenchment of the molecular weight range from 74 to 493 Da which corresponds to: monomers (with dominant molecular mass signals, m/z of 193, 223), dimers (with dominant molecular mass signals, m/z of 272, 283, 297), and some possible trimer traces. The depolymerisation of lignin with predilection to dimers over Ru-based catalyst was also confirmed by HPSEC analysis (Fig. 8 ), in agreement with previously reported literature [17]. However, over (RuNiMgAlO)x the conversion of lignin decreased from 86% (obtained over (RuNiAlO)x) to 83%. The decrease of the lignin conversion and increase of the molecular weight range from 74 to 493 Da compared to that from m/z of 74–414 Da (over (RuNiAlO)x) can be due to the lower acidity, whereas the cleavage of CC bond takes place preferentially on the acid sites [70]. Recently, Jiang Y et al. reported that the combination of Raney Ni with an acidic zeolite led to an improvement in the depolymerisation of cellulolytic enzyme lignin in a methanol/water solvent mixture at 250 °C [71]. The LDI-TOF-MS analysis also gave rise to dominant mass signals in the molecular weight range of dimeric products in the depolymerisation of lignin over 5%Ru/Al2O3, even if the oxidation state of the supported ruthenium was zero. Therefore, the presence of ruthenium led to dimers formation in the depolymersiation of lignin under autoclave conditions. An interesting aspect observed after HPSEC analysis was the identification of a molecular weight range smaller compared to those obtained over Ru-mixed oxides catalysts. This aspect can be due to the increase in the active hydrogen species on metal sites which leads to a better hydrogenolysis of the lignin [72]. On the other hand, depolymerisation of lignin over Ru/Al2O3 led to the formation of new dimers with m/z (301, 331, 369, 385, 417). The three basic monomers (coniferyl, sinapyl and p-coumaryl alcohols) are connected by several linkages as β-O-4, α-O-4, β-5, 5-5, 4-O-5, β-1 and β-β [73]. If the β-O-4 and α-O-4 linkages can be easily cleaved, the 5,5-(biphenyl)-type and aromatic ring structures are much more stable [74]. The higher stability of CC bond comparted with that of CO bond was also highlighted by R. Parthasarathi et al. [75]. On the other hand H. Chen et al. showed a positive effect of the linkages between Ru and Ni in the CC bond-breaking selectivity [76]. Moreover, the dimer structures are formed by monomer structures linked by CC bond. Therefore, the absence of nickel may explain the formation of new dimer structures upon depolymerisation of lignin over (Ru/Al2O3)x. An increase of amount of Ru/Al2O3 catalyst from 10% to 20% (wt) was also accompanied by a slightly increase of the catalytic performances of the catalyst (Fig. 9 ). An increase in the hydrogen partial pressure from 50 to 70 bar in the depolymerisation of lignin over (RuNiAlO)x led to a decrease in the average molecular mass of reaction products (Fig. 10 ). This positive effect of hydrogen pressure over hydrogenolysis processes is in agreement with literature data [77]. In view of the results of the catalytic activity of the aforementioned Ru-based catalysts in the depolymerisation of lignin, (RuNiAlO)x was selected for the recycling test. After the first catalytic cycle, the conversion falls significantly down to 55% and it remained almost the same for the next three catalytic cycles. An interesting aspect was observed during the fourth catalytic cycle, namely an increase in the weight of monomers with an increase in the number of catalytic cycles (Fig. 11 ). In spite of the fact that ruthenium leaching was not detect upon the reaction, the decrease in the conversion can be due to sulfur poisoning (a 476 ppm sulfur concentration was detected by EDXRF technique) whereas the recovery of lignin from black liquor was carried out by precipitation with a sulfuric acid solution [24]. Recently, C. Yuan et al. reported that an addition of Ru to Ni/SiO2-P catalyst improved its tolerance to sulfur. Therefore, the coexistence of Ru with Ni as well as the acidity of the catalyst inhibits its complete sulfur poisoning [78,79]. The linkage between ruthenium and nickel reduced the sulfur adsorption on the (RuNiAlO)x which explains the catalytic activity of this catalyst even after four catalytic cycles. Blocking of the active sites of ruthenium with sulfur led to an increase of the monomers weight (Fig. 11). 4 Conclusions The lignin subjected to depolymerization was extracted in basic medium from the Mischantus plant. The mixed oxides or ruthenium supported on alumina tested in order to break down lignin to low molecular mass compounds were prepared by calcination of layered double hydroxides and wet impregnation, respectively. The presence of metallic or oxidized ruthenium as part of these catalysts was evidenced by XRD, H2-TPR, Raman and XPS techniques, while NH3-TPD technique evidenced the acid properties of these materials. The hydrogenolysis of depolymerisation was carried out under autoclave conditions and the reaction products were analyzed by several techniques such as LDI-TOF-MS, HPSEC and GC–MS. Specifically, the presence of ruthenium in the structure of mixed oxides led to dimers formation. Besides the presence of ruthenium and its oxidation state, the amount of nickel had an influence in the depolymerisation performance of lignin, increasing slightly with the nickel content. Another factor which influenced the catalytic performance was the acidity, thus the depolymerisation of lignin over Ru supported on alumina led to the highest degree of lignin depolymerisation (conversion 89%), but the best selectivity in the dimers production was obtained over (RuNiAlO)x due to bimetallic synergism. Although the Ru-based catalysts didn’t show leaching after depolymerisation process, the presence of sulfur led to a decrease in the lignin conversion to small molecular weight compounds upon consecutive recycling tests as well as to lower selectivity towards dimers. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic performances of two different classes of catalysts containing nickel or/and ruthenium as the active sites were studied in the depolymerisation of lignin isolated from Miscanthus × giganteus. The catalysts were prepared either by coprecipitation (ie, (RuNiMgAlO)x, (RuNiAlO)x, (NiAlO)x, (NiMgAlO)x) or by wet impregnation (ie, Ru/Al2O3) and characterized by nitrogen physisorption (BET), XRD, XPS, NH3-TPD, Raman and H2-TPR techniques. The experimental results indicate that the presence of ruthenium led to dimers as dominant products.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenolysis of lignin over Ru-based catalysts: The role of the ruthenium in a lignin fragmentation process
